quote: Given only that we are psychologically compelled to see the world as being such that, in it, thus and such is the case, it doesn't follow that thus and such really is the case. A psychotic may be psychologically compelled to see pink elephants, but that doesn't mean there are pink elephants.

claim: Kant admits intuitions only tell us about the phenomenal world, not the noumenal world
text: Kant admits intuitions only tell us about the phenomenal world, not the noumenal world
quote: Actually, Kant himself admits this. These intuitions, he says, tell us about the "phenomenal" world, not the "noumenal" world. By Kant's own definition, the "phenomenal world" is just the world as it appears to us: it is how we see the world. The "noumenal" world is the actual world.

claim: On Kant's view, intuitions give us no knowledge of the external world or concepts
text: On Kant's view, intuitions give us no knowledge of the external world or concepts
quote: So, on Kant's view, intuitions don't tell us anything about the spatiotemporal world and they don't tell us anything about concepts. Thus, given only that intuition tells us that a straight line is the shortest distance between two points, we simply have no reason to believe that straight line is the shortest distance between two points.

claim: Kant's system makes supposedly a priori truths into empirical truths
text: Kant's system makes supposedly a priori truths into empirical truths
quote: So on Kant's view, followed to its logical conclusion, for us to know whether 7+5 really equaled 12, we'd have to learn some fact about the non-mental, non-platonic world (which, for reasons that are internal to Kant's system, Kant says we cannot do). 7+5=12 thus becomes a kind of empirical truth.

claim: Mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis
text: Mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis
quote: When you learn through mental imagery that a straight line intersects a circle at no more than two points, you are learning something that holds entirely in virtue of facts about the structures of the concepts CIRCLE and LINE, and so forth. You are not learning something that holds in virtue of facts about our cognitive machinery.

claim: Kant failed to distinguish different epistemological roles of mental imagery
text: Kant failed to distinguish different epistemological roles of mental imagery
quote: What led Kant astray was a failure to distinguish the different roles that mental imagery can play in the acquisition of knowledge. Kant noted that mental imagery is a kind of para-perception. He concluded from this that, when mental imagery is involved in the discovery of some truth, that truth is synthetic  like those truths that we use perception to discover.

claim: Determining the minimum number of sides a solid can have involves conceptual analysis via imagery
text: Determining the minimum number of sides a solid can have involves conceptual analysis via imagery
quote: If somebody asks me "what is the minimum number of sides a solid can have?", I base my answer on a mental image that I produce. I imagine trying to produce a solid out of four sides, then note that it doesn't work, then try to do the same thing with five sides, and note that it does work. But surely the fact that a solid has to have a minimum of five sides is not synthetic.

claim: Mental imagery can serve different epistemic roles - conceptual analysis vs. empirical observation
text: Mental imagery can serve different epistemic roles - conceptual analysis vs. empirical observation
quote: mental imagery can sometimes serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis. But it can also play a very different epistemic role. Suppose I want to find out facts about my own psychology. Suppose, for example, that I want to find out whether I can imagine a 17-sided figure. Here I will, of course, generate mental imagery, and attend to the content of that imagery. But in this case, the imagery is not serving as a vehicle for conceptual analysis.

claim: Knowledge about representational limitations is a posteriori
text: Knowledge about representational limitations is a posteriori
quote: For Kant, you learn that you can't represent parallel lines as intersecting by noting that you cannot imagine it; you observe your own mental imagery. So you learn this putative fact about your representational powers through a kind of self-observation, and not through any kind of conceptual analysis. This knowledge turns out to be quite a posteriori.

claim: Leibniz argued that mathematical demonstrations don't derive their cogency from diagrams
text: Leibniz argued that mathematical demonstrations don't derive their cogency from diagrams
quote: But I do not agree with you what seems to be your [Locke's] view, that some kind of general certainty is provided in mathematics by "particular demonstrations" concerning the diagram that has been drawn. You must understand that geometers do not derive their proofs from diagrams, although the expository approach makes it seem so. The cogency of the demonstration is independent of the diagram, whose only role is to make it easier to understand what is meant and to fix one's attention.

claim: Peacocke's distinction between access and justification applies to mental imagery
text: Peacocke's distinction between access and justification applies to mental imagery
quote: When you come to know a logical truth by way of your having a proof of it, you may need to perceive the inscription of the proof, and you may need various perceptual capacities to appreciate that it is a proof. But the justification for your belief in the logical truth is the proof itself. Perceptual experience gives access to the proof, which provides an experience-independent justification for accepting its conclusion.

claim: Transcendental necessity is either psychological or conceptual necessity
text: Transcendental necessity is either psychological or conceptual necessity
quote: In the end, "transcendental" necessity reduces either to mere psychological necessity or to conceptual necessity. We cannot coherently think of a world where triangles have two sides or where 2+2=3. That is because propositions like 2+2=3 and triangles have two sides are conceptually false and consequently draw a limit to what we can conceive of.

claim: Conceptual necessities impose limits on visual representation
text: Conceptual necessities impose limits on visual representation
quote: What cannot be conceived cannot be perceived. Conceptual necessities thus impose sharp limits on how the world can be visually represented. So it is clear how conceptual falsity translates into representational impossibility.

claim: There is an incoherence in Kant's thinking about mathematical propositions
text: There is an incoherence in Kant's thinking about mathematical propositions
quote: There is an incoherence in Kant's thinking more radical than any mentioned so far. He rightly wants to hold that propositions like 7+2=9 and the area of a (Euclidean) triangle is  the baseheight are a priori. But he also says that we sense-perceive the world as being such that these propositions are true in it.

claim: Mathematical propositions don't describe the spatiotemporal world
text: Mathematical propositions don't describe the spatiotemporal world
quote: But, as Frege clearly stated, 7+2=9 doesn't say anything about the spatio-temporal world; it doesn't say that if you hold up two fingers and then hold up seven fingers, nine fingers are on display. For there could, in principle, be a causal law that falsified just that sort of statement  a law that didn't allow more than five fingers to be simultaneously on display in a certain region.

claim: Kant's position requires mathematical propositions to be both descriptive and non-descriptive of the world
text: Kant's position requires mathematical propositions to be both descriptive and non-descriptive of the world
quote: So Kant's position is self-undermining. He needs mathematical propositions to be two things at once. They must be descriptive of the world: they must say something about beams of light. But they must also not be descriptive of the world: they must not be capable of falsification by anything having to do with beams of light and the like.

claim: If a proposition is necessary, it doesn't describe the empirical world
text: If a proposition is necessary, it doesn't describe the empirical world
quote: But there is an inference from P is necessarily true to P doesn't describe the empirical world (in any way at all). If P is necessary, then P's being true in world 1 doesn't distinguish world 1 from world 2 or from world 897. P therefore doesn't say anything about the world that distinguishes it from other possible worlds.

claim: Kant's conception of analyticity is too narrow, and this is the fundamental error in his system
text: Kant's conception of analyticity is too narrow, and this is the fundamental error in his system
quote: Ultimately, there is one thing wrong with Kant's view: his conception of analyticity is much too narrow. Everything else that is wrong about Kant's position can be traced back to this one mistake. A corollary is that everything that is wrong about his system can be corrected by correcting this one mistake.

claim: Kant grants analytic status only to trivial propositions like 'circles are round'
text: Kant grants analytic status only to trivial propositions like 'circles are round'
quote: Kant grants analytic status only to propositions like (a) circles are round. He denies analytic status to propositions like (b) a circle is a class of points equidistant from a given point in a plane.

claim: Hard analytic truths are logically but not psychologically incoherent to deny
text: Hard analytic truths are logically but not psychologically incoherent to deny
quote: Let us set say that (b) and (e) are "hard analytic", and let us say that (a) and (h) are "easy analytic". It is hard to know that (b) and (e) are true. It is not hard to know (a) and (h) are analytic; a grasp of those propositions by itself suffices for a knowledge of their truth.

claim: What Kant calls synthetic a priori truths are actually hard analytic truths
text: What Kant calls synthetic a priori truths are actually hard analytic truths
quote: What Kant refers to as "synthetic a priori" truths are nothing other than what we are describing as hard analytic truths. What Kant refers to as analytic truths are what we are describing as easy analytic truths.

claim: Recognizing hard analytic truths eliminates the need for psychologistic analysis
text: Recognizing hard analytic truths eliminates the need for psychologistic analysis
quote: Once it is recognized that (b) and (e) are analytic, albeit hard analytic, we must say that they hold entirely in virtue of facts about the concepts that compose them; and there is no longer any temptation to say that they are made true by facts about the mind. So that obliterates any possible warrant that might otherwise be had by Kant's psychologistic analysis of those propositions.

claim: Kant's main concern is understanding how the world must be structured for coherent experience to be possible
text: Kant's main concern is understanding how the world must be structured for coherent experience to be possible
quote: We have experience; we have sequences of thoughts and perceptions that cohere. The world is intelligible to us. We sense-perceive it and about it. Up to a point, our perceptions and thoughts are accurate. In Kant's view, given the very fact that these things are true, we can deduce certain things about the structure of the world.

claim: Transcendental conditions are necessarily satisfied by any world containing entities with coherent thoughts
text: Transcendental conditions are necessarily satisfied by any world containing entities with coherent thoughts
quote: Kant refers to those conditions as "transcendental": they are the conditions that are necessarily satisfied by any world in which there are entities that have coherent, if not always accurate, thoughts and representations.

claim: A transcendental argument has the form: given experience of a certain kind, the world must have certain features
text: A transcendental argument has the form: given experience of a certain kind, the world must have certain features
quote: A "transcendental argument" is one having the form: given only that we have experiences of such and such a kind, it follows that the world must have thus and such features.

claim: There is a hard analytic connection between beings capable of metaphysical questions and propositions about world structure
text: There is a hard analytic connection between beings capable of metaphysical questions and propositions about world structure
quote: I will argue that there is an analytic connection  a hard analytic connection, but an analytic connection no less  between the proposition there exist beings who have the cognitive wherewithal to raise metaphysical questions and propositions concerning the structure of the world itself.

claim: A world without causation would comprise nothing enduring
text: A world without causation would comprise nothing enduring
quote: Imagine a world where there is no causation, where there are merely sequences of events. Such a world would comprise nothing enduring. This is because persistence is itself a causal notion. If something persists, there is ipso facto a causal sequence of some kind.

claim: Coherent ideation requires persistence, which requires causation
text: Coherent ideation requires persistence, which requires causation
quote: Where there is no persistence, there is no coherent ideation. For surely, as a matter of necessity, a coherent thought process involves some kind of persistence. So given only the fact that there are beings who have the ability to raise questions about anything, let alone about the necessary preconditions for experience, it follows that causal relations do not consist in mere sequences of events, but in internal relations of some kind.

claim: This transcendental argument relies on analytic connections, not synthetic a priori truths
text: This transcendental argument relies on analytic connections, not synthetic a priori truths
quote: But notice that this transcendental argument turns on the existence of entirely analytic connections among propositions; no "synthetic a priori" is involved. Given the very concept of a rational thought process, it follows that analytically there are causal relations among events.

claim: Hume's induction problem: past experience cannot justify future expectations without circular reasoning
text: Hume's induction problem: past experience cannot justify future expectations without circular reasoning
quote: Suppose that such and such has always happened in the past. How does our knowledge of that fact warrant our believing that such and such will happen in the future? The warrant is not deductive. Given only that such and such happened before time t, there is no logical contradiction in saying that it won't happen after t.

claim: Justifying induction requires the principle that the future resembles the past, but this is itself empirical
text: Justifying induction requires the principle that the future resembles the past, but this is itself empirical
quote: To have an empirical justification for that inference, we'd have to know that, in general, the future resembles the past and that, consequently, knowledge of the past gives us a rational basis for beliefs about the future. But that is itself an empirical thesis, whose only possible justification lies in our past experience.

claim: Hume's causation problem: there are no logical connections between distinct events
text: Hume's causation problem: there are no logical connections between distinct events
quote: Given two distinct states of affairs, one is not guilty of self-contradiction if one affirms the existence of the one but denies the existence of the other. Since causality holds between distinct states of affairs, there is no strictly logical connection between cause and effect.

claim: Causal forces cannot be empirically justified because we only perceive events, not connections
text: Causal forces cannot be empirically justified because we only perceive events, not connections
quote: We perceive events and regularities among events. If they exist, forces are connections among events, and are not events themselves. What we perceive gives us a basis for believing that certain kinds of events are likely to accompany certain other kinds of events. But what we perceive does not give us any basis for perceiving that things altogether different from events are likely to accompany events.

claim: Hume's position must be qualified: logical relations hold between propositions, not events
text: Hume's position must be qualified: logical relations hold between propositions, not events
quote: Hume says that given any two distinct events, there is no strictly logical connection between them. This must be qualified. Logical relations hold, not between states of affairs, but between pieces of information. Typically, these pieces of information are held to be sentences or propositions.

claim: Whether propositions about events are logically connected depends on how we describe the events
text: Whether propositions about events are logically connected depends on how we describe the events
quote: But this last statement, in its turn, is true only when subject to a heavy qualification. Depending on how we describe A and B, a proposition affirming the existence of the one might entail one affirming the existence of the other.

claim: That simple descriptions don't entail each other doesn't prove events lack internal connections
text: That simple descriptions don't entail each other doesn't prove events lack internal connections
quote: For similar reasons, given only that (*) doesn't entail (**), we cannot infer that A and B have only a contingent relation to each other. What we can infer is either that A is only contingently related to B or that (*) and (**) leave out the relevant data. I believe that (*) and (**) leave out the relevant data, and that the relation between A and B is in no way contingent.

claim: There are no instantaneous states of affairs
text: There are no instantaneous states of affairs
quote: Are there instantaneous states of affairs? Is there anything that exists in three, but not in four, dimensions? Of course, we sometimes speak about instantaneous states of affairs. But, it is now generally held, such talk is elliptical for talk of arbitrarily short, non-instantaneous states of affairs.

claim: Talk of instantaneous properties is elliptical for limit-statements about intervals
text: Talk of instantaneous properties is elliptical for limit-statements about intervals
quote: When we say that such that such and such is what obtains at a given instant t, we mean that what obtains during smaller and smaller intervals containing t approximates arbitrarily well to such and such.

claim: There are no strictly non-dynamic spatiotemporal properties
text: There are no strictly non-dynamic spatiotemporal properties
quote: But exactly similar considerations warrant the view that there can no instantaneous temperature, mass, color, shape, spin, and so on. There are no strictly non-dynamic spatiotemporal properties  no property such that possession of it doesn't involve movement.

claim: No complete description of any state of affairs can avoid temporal duration
text: No complete description of any state of affairs can avoid temporal duration
quote: A corollary is that there is no complete description of any state of affairs that does not say what happens over a stretch of time.

claim: Complete descriptions of events must include descriptions of subsequent events
text: Complete descriptions of events must include descriptions of subsequent events
quote: In that case, a complete description of the occurrences during int would include a description of occurrences happening after int. So a complete description of the relevant mass-energy displacement (the relevant electron-jump or whatnot) would include a description of some later event E.

claim: If complete descriptions include subsequent events, this shatters Hume's view of no necessary connections
text: If complete descriptions include subsequent events, this shatters Hume's view of no necessary connections
quote: This would have two consequences. First it would mean that any description of any given event would include a description of subsequent events. That by itself would shatter Hume's view that there is no necessary connection between any event and any subsequent event.

claim: There would be logical connections between events connected by continuous series
text: There would be logical connections between events connected by continuous series
quote: By this reasoning, there is a strictly logical connection between (complete descriptions of) any two events that are connected by a continuous series of events.

claim: Payment of bonuses enormously improves productivity without any doubt
text: Payment of bonuses enormously improves productivity without any doubt
quote: Does the payment of bonuses really improve productivity? Yes, enormously, without any doubt.

claim: Bonuses work differently for creative versus low-level workers - talent must be rewarded while low-level workers are less motivated by bonuses
text: Bonuses work differently for creative versus low-level workers - talent must be rewarded while low-level workers are less motivated by bonuses
quote: If you are dealing with low level workersboozers who are putting rocks in a bagthen not so much, since they are more interested in how little they can do and get by than they are in moving forward. But with talentgotta reward it.

claim: A consistent set of sentences can be extended to a maximal consistent set through a specific construction
text: A consistent set of sentences can be extended to a maximal consistent set through a specific construction
quote: Let S be a consistent statement set, and let s1 be an arbitrary statement not in S. If s1 is consistent with S, then the union of S and s1 is consistent; otherwise, the union of S and not s1 is consistent.

claim: The distinction between good and bad clients is utterly sharp and predictable
text: The distinction between good and bad clients is utterly sharp and predictable
quote: The line good between clients and dirty clients is utterly sharp. There are good clients who are annoying and may even be bad people in some contexts, but they pay and they are honest about what you have done for them.

claim: Bad clients reveal themselves quickly through dishonesty about work performed
text: Bad clients reveal themselves quickly through dishonesty about work performed
quote: The dirty clients lie about what you done-and they show their true colors pretty much right away (after one or two meetings, sometimes one or two minutes).

claim: Social media influencers provide value by facilitating information flow
text: Social media influencers provide value by facilitating information flow
quote: Social media facilitates the flow of information, and social media influencers can help people benefit from that increased flow

claim: Starting a startup straight out of college is advisable if you have a legitimate business idea
text: Starting a startup straight out of college is advisable if you have a legitimate business idea
quote: If you have a legitimate business idea, then you have more answers than just about anyone you come across, and you should go for it.

claim: People in miserable jobs tend to discourage others from pursuing good business ideas
text: People in miserable jobs tend to discourage others from pursuing good business ideas
quote: if you ask other people if your idea is good, they are likely to say no if it is good and yes if it is bad, because they are stuck at miserable jobs and want you to be stuck with them.

claim: Facebook demonstrates that ideas that seem bad on paper can still succeed
text: Facebook demonstrates that ideas that seem bad on paper can still succeed
quote: Considered on paper, is Facebook a good idea? Probably not, but it worked, and thats the end of it.

claim: Several scientific paradoxes were later proven logical, including framework invariance of speed of light
text: Several scientific paradoxes were later proven logical, including framework invariance of speed of light
quote: 1. Framework invariance of speed of light 2. Non-additivity of length and mass 3. Existence of unconscious 4. Absence of deterministic model of quantum phenomena

claim: Species-level fitness is often opposite to individual-level fitness
text: Species-level fitness is often opposite to individual-level fitness
quote: Species level fitness often opposite of individual level fitness (cows as a species highly successful, even though any given cow is heading to the slaughter house; genius members of homo sapiens very successful even though the genius subpopulation is proving not so good at keeping itself going)

claim: Procuring/pimping doesn't deserve its bad reputation when conducted properly
text: Procuring/pimping doesn't deserve its bad reputation when conducted properly
quote: procuring, meaning being a pimp or madam. those professions, when conducted properly, minimize the spread of disease and provide healthy outlets for energies that are otherwise expressed neurotically.

claim: It is absolutely acceptable for a man to hit a woman in self-defense without qualifications
text: It is absolutely acceptable for a man to hit a woman in self-defense without qualifications
quote: Is it ever acceptable for a man to hit a woman in self-defense? Absolutely. 100%. No qualifications.

claim: Mathematical logic is sterile and poorly taught, which explains lack of interest
text: Mathematical logic is sterile and poorly taught, which explains lack of interest
quote: Mathematical logic is a bit sterile, and thats probably what youre picking up on. Plus, the people who teach it are kind of in the weeds, in terms of ability-level and vision.

claim: No single case exists of an anomaly being definitively resolved by two incompatible hypotheses
text: No single case exists of an anomaly being definitively resolved by two incompatible hypotheses
quote: Identify a single case of a given anomaly being definitively resolved by two incompatible hypotheses. No such case exists.

claim: Nothing mathematically proven is false, though there are counterintuitive models of axioms
text: Nothing mathematically proven is false, though there are counterintuitive models of axioms
quote: Short answer-no: since nothing proven is false. Long answer-there have turned out to be models of axioms that seem self-evidently false.

claim: Non-Euclidean geometry provides models where the parallel axiom is false and describes actual space
text: Non-Euclidean geometry provides models where the parallel axiom is false and describes actual space
quote: There are models in which the parallel axiom (parallels dont intersect) is false, and one of those models describes actual space.

claim: Macroeconomics is social psychology insofar as it relates to commercial behavior
text: Macroeconomics is social psychology insofar as it relates to commercial behavior
quote: Macroeconomics is social psychology, in so far as the latter relates to commercial behavior.

claim: Randomness is not more important than effort and talent in determining life outcomes
text: Randomness is not more important than effort and talent in determining life outcomes
quote: How important is randomness in life? Is it more important than effort and talent? Absolutely not. It is is very hard to keep someone down if he has talent and character.

claim: Standardized tests are efficient for approximate knowledge but limited for individuals
text: Standardized tests are efficient for approximate knowledge but limited for individuals
quote: Standardized tests are extraordinarily efficient and are indicated in contexts where only very approximate knowledge is necessary or where knowledge about whole populations (e.g. people who may have been exposed to toxins leading to psychological impairments) are necessary. With individuals, they are of limited use

claim: Bad thoughts about Allah occur because religious tyranny constrains freedom
text: Bad thoughts about Allah occur because religious tyranny constrains freedom
quote: You think bad thoughts about Allah because you want to be free and somebody is using religious tyranny to constrain you. Accept that, and your intrusive thoughts about Allah will vanish.

claim: All people understand mathematics; mathematical talent is about operationalizing this understanding in new contexts
text: All people understand mathematics; mathematical talent is about operationalizing this understanding in new contexts
quote: I think that all people do understand it. What we refer to as mathematical talent is about being able to operationalize mathematical intelligence outside of those contexts in which it is automatically operational.

claim: School does not provide the tools needed for adulthood
text: School does not provide the tools needed for adulthood
quote: Does school give us the tools we need in our adulthood? No it doesnt. It doesnt give us the requisite technical skills. Nor does it give us the requisite understanding of the economy or of its psychological underpinnings.

claim: Simply viewing websites cannot lead to arrest; transactional engagement is required
text: Simply viewing websites cannot lead to arrest; transactional engagement is required
quote: you have to make a purchase or otherwise engage the website in a transactional manner. otherwise no.

claim: It is a moral obligation to visit morally questionable websites to resist bureaucratic control
text: It is a moral obligation to visit morally questionable websites to resist bureaucratic control
quote: you should actually see it as your moral obligation to visit as many morally questionable websites as possible , since not doing so means conceding moral legitimacy to blockhead bureaucrats and moralizing phonies.

claim: It is not essential to study the same subject for PhD as for master's thesis
text: It is not essential to study the same subject for PhD as for master's thesis
quote: absolutely not. my masters thesis was on definite descriptions, and my doctoral thesis was on legal positivism.

claim: Being able to financially destroy someone through marriage is morally wrong but legal
text: Being able to financially destroy someone through marriage is morally wrong but legal
quote: Being able to destroy somebody financially simply because you were married to them.

claim: Thoughts of hurting a cat are the mind's way of indicating sexual needs
text: Thoughts of hurting a cat are the mind's way of indicating sexual needs
quote: You want to hurt your cat-your minds way of telling you that you need to pound some p*ssy. Not hard to decrypt.

claim: Men and women cannot be friends because they want different things from each other
text: Men and women cannot be friends because they want different things from each other
quote: Because men dont want friendship from women, and women dont want friendship from men. Men want sex and love (in that order) from women, and women want love and sex (in that order) from men.

claim: OCD can recrudesce at any point but is unlikely to originate after adolescence
text: OCD can recrudesce at any point but is unlikely to originate after adolescence
quote: It can certainly recrudesce at any juncture in life. But it is not likely to come into existence after adolescence.

claim: Identity has a fixed true self; what is fluid is how one lives out this true self
text: Identity has a fixed true self; what is fluid is how one lives out this true self
quote: What is fluid is how your live out your true self, not what your true self is.

claim: Teachers will be the next major job replaced by robots
text: Teachers will be the next major job replaced by robots
quote: The next big oneteachers. Most of that is best automated.

claim: Philosophers abandoned logical atomism because physical simplicity doesn't equal conceptual simplicity
text: Philosophers abandoned logical atomism because physical simplicity doesn't equal conceptual simplicity
quote: Two reasons. (1) Physical simplicity doesnt equate to conceptual simplicity. (2) Whether a given statement is to be regarded as complex, and how exactly it is to be regarded as complex, depends on the dialectical context.

claim: There are no ultimate foundational truths because any truth entails and is entailed by infinitely many others
text: There are no ultimate foundational truths because any truth entails and is entailed by infinitely many others
quote: Any given truth is entailed by infinitely many others and itself entails infinitely many truths. And since a statements entailment-relations (what it entails and what it entails it) reflect its structure, there are no ultimate, foundational truths.

claim: Men can mature emotionally in the sense of learning how their welfare connects to others
text: Men can mature emotionally in the sense of learning how their welfare connects to others

quote: Truth is a relationship between idea and external referent. Descartes is saying that he will discard the referent; and in the absence of said referent, it cannot be said whether or not the idea is true or false.

quote: The most dangerous question in philosophy is whether there can be political solutions to biologically or culturally rooted problems.

claim: Zeno's paradox shows motion presupposes prior motion, leading to the conclusion nothing moves
text: Zeno's paradox shows motion presupposes prior motion, leading to the conclusion nothing moves
quote: In order to travel a distance of n yards, it is necessary to travel a distance of n/10 yards... (i) one cannot travel any distance at all without already having traveled some smaller distance. Consequently, (ii) Any given motion presupposes a prior motion... (v) Nothing moves.

claim: Mills' solution to Zeno's paradox fails because it eliminates continuity of identity
text: Mills' solution to Zeno's paradox fails because it eliminates continuity of identity
quote: If you are obliterated and some person who is exactly like you appears a moment later right next to where you were standing, that person isnt you.

claim: Russell's solution fails because it doesn't explain how the first step can be taken
text: Russell's solution fails because it doesn't explain how the first step can be taken
quote: Zeno is asking how a given object can take that first step... Russell hasnt answered that question. He has only made the irrelevant point that if a given object can move that first inch, then it can, after an infinite series of further motions, move a second inch.

claim: The actual solution to Zeno's paradox is that all position is relative and motion is systemic change
text: The actual solution to Zeno's paradox is that all position is relative and motion is systemic change
quote: All position is relative position. Therefore, changes in position are changes in relative position... What we think of as a case of motion on the part of a given object xi is really a change undergone by x1xn collectively.

claim: Gdel was not influenced by Wittgenstein because they held opposite views on mathematical realism
text: Gdel was not influenced by Wittgenstein because they held opposite views on mathematical realism
quote: He was not. Godel an arch-Platonist and arch-realist about mathematical entities... Wittgenstein, by contrast, was a radical anti-realist. His position was that mathematical truths are pure conventionsmere games.

claim: Logic as taught is a heap of artifacts that fails to automate thought effectively
text: Logic as taught is a heap of artifacts that fails to automate thought effectively
quote: logic, as it is taught in philosophy and even in math departments, is a heap of artifacts. supposedly the discipline is meant to discover ways to automate thought, but the algorithms it produces to that end require more thought to use than they succeed in automating.

text: Academic papers are useless because nobody reads them and they contain no meaningful content

quote: Incompleteness implies mechanical but not absolute undecidability. For a statement-set to be incomplete is for there to be no recursion that generates it.

text: An incompleteness theorem is one that shows there is no recursive definition of a given statement-class
quote: An incompleteness theorem is one to the effect that there is no recursive definition of a given statement-class.

claim: The first incompleteness theorem was Cantor's proof that there is no recursive definition of the class of truths about real numbers
text: The first incompleteness theorem was Cantor's proof that there is no recursive definition of the class of truths about real numbers
quote: The first such theorem was that there is no recursive definition of the class of truths of the form x is a real number. This was proved by George Cantor in the 1870s, and the proof involved a technique known as diagonalization.

claim: Godel tried to create a recursive definition of arithmetical truths, failed, then proved it was impossible using diagonalization
text: Godel tried to create a recursive definition of arithmetical truths, failed, then proved it was impossible using diagonalization
quote: Fifty years later, Godel tried to come up with a recursive definition of the class of arithmetical truths. He couldnt and then decided to prove that no such definition was possible. He succeeded. His proof involved an exotic form of diagonalization.

claim: Nothing flies in the face of logic but is still true, because contradictions between facts and logic mean the wrong logic is being used
text: Nothing flies in the face of logic but is still true, because contradictions between facts and logic mean the wrong logic is being used

text: Abductive reasoning is simply hypothesis-formation

claim: Abductive reasoning example: cheese disappearing with mouse-sized bites and footprints leads to hypothesis that a mouse is eating the cheese
text: Abductive reasoning example: cheese disappearing with mouse-sized bites and footprints leads to hypothesis that a mouse is eating the cheese
quote: Your cheese is vanishing. You notice an increasing number of mouse-size bites out of your hunk of cheddar cheese and an increasing number of mouse-size footprints in vicinity of said cheese. You hypothesize, i.e. abductively reason, that a mouse is eating your cheese. This is abductive inference.

claim: Abductive reasoning has innumerable benefits over deduction because you cannot deduce many empirical conclusions
text: Abductive reasoning has innumerable benefits over deduction because you cannot deduce many empirical conclusions
quote: As for its benefits over deduction, they are innumerable. You cannot deduce that a mouse is eating your cheese.

claim: Deductive reasoning works when conclusions are analytically contained in premises, but not for empirical hypotheses
text: Deductive reasoning works when conclusions are analytically contained in premises, but not for empirical hypotheses
quote: If you can know that x is a triangle, you can deduce that x has three sides, since x is a triangle is analytically incompatible with x does not have three sides. But a mouse is not eating my cheese is not analytically compatible with the aforementioned data.

claim: It is impossible to create a logical system without modus ponens because it is essential for inference
text: It is impossible to create a logical system without modus ponens because it is essential for inference
quote: Not possible. Modus ponens is basically to the effect that you can infer it if it follows. Without it, you are in dry dock, inference-wise.

claim: Alternative formulations of modus ponens don't eliminate it since they rely on definitional equivalences
text: Alternative formulations of modus ponens don't eliminate it since they rely on definitional equivalences
quote: Of course, you can always tinker with the way it is expressed. Instead of saying ((P->Q) &P)->Q, you can say: -((-P or Q)&Q)&-Q) But given that P->Q is definitionally equivalent with -P or Q, this isnt exactly a way to get rid of modus ponens.

text: College dropouts often make rational decisions based on cost-benefit analysis
quote: When people drop out, it is usually (not always) because it isn't worth it for them to stay

claim: Knowledge management cannot help universities because they depend on poor internal communications
text: Knowledge management cannot help universities because they depend on poor internal communications
quote: Unlike OMC's, universities actually depend on poor internal communications

claim: Knowledge Management explains how institutions must organize to optimize information flow
text: Knowledge Management explains how institutions must organize to optimize information flow
quote: KM explains how institutions must be organized if knowledge-exchanges that must occur are to occur

claim: University departments remain isolated to protect professors from scrutiny
text: University departments remain isolated to protect professors from scrutiny
quote: if a philosophy professor teamed up with an economics professor, that philosophy professor could (and probably would) be called out economics students who were not under his thumb

claim: The solution is to create new educational institutions rather than reform existing universities
text: The solution is to create new educational institutions rather than reform existing universities
quote: if one wants to improve education and to make money doing so, there is at the current an enormous opportunity. Right now is the perfect time to make education affordable, fast, effective, and also (for the owner of the educational service in question) extremely lucrative

claim: DMO will be a results-based online university that sells competence rather than prestige
text: DMO will be a results-based online university that sells competence rather than prestige
quote: The most important fact about DMO is that students pay for results, not services. Therefore, a degree from DMO must be proof of competence. DMO does not sell prestige; it sells competence

claim: Organizations that sell results have well-defined objectives enabling good knowledge management
text: Organizations that sell results have well-defined objectives enabling good knowledge management
quote: Knowledge-management is possible when the organization in question has definite objectives, and when it does not have definite objectives, knowledge-management is as difficult as those objectives are vague

claim: Service organizations depend on poor knowledge management to maintain inefficiencies
text: Service organizations depend on poor knowledge management to maintain inefficiencies
quote: When people within a given organization have an incentive to block communications within it, information tends to be blocked, and people within service organizations tend to have such incentives

claim: Education must be digitized whenever possible for efficiency and cost reduction
text: Education must be digitized whenever possible for efficiency and cost reduction
quote: when education can be digitized, it must be digitized... since doing so saves time and money and makes it easy for purchase custom-made education from the best instructors at the lowest possible price

claim: At DMO, instructors are paid directly by students based on performance, not by the institution
text: At DMO, instructors are paid directly by students based on performance, not by the institution
quote: students must negotiate prices directly with instructors, and payments must go straight to the instructor. The instructor will give a percentage of his earnings to DMO in exchange for use of the platform, business volume, credibility, instructional materials, and the like

claim: DMO will use independent examination-based accreditation rather than instructor grading
text: DMO will use independent examination-based accreditation rather than instructor grading
quote: At DMO, instructors do not issue grades. There are no grades. There are accreditations. Accreditations are attained by taking examinations. These examinations are graded anonymously (by computer, whenever possible). They are designed and administered by independent third parties

claim: DMO will convert liberal arts students to STEM through 'lite' science degrees
text: DMO will convert liberal arts students to STEM through 'lite' science degrees
quote: Its primary solution will be to offer lite science degrees: lite-physics, lite-math; math for computer scientists; lite biology. In this way, DMO gets people out of the doldrums of the liberal arts and into STEM

claim: DMO will be non-discriminatory and service all students unlike traditional universities
text: DMO will be non-discriminatory and service all students unlike traditional universities
quote: DMO has the first business model. Other universities have the second... If universities really sold instructionin other words, if they made their money by seeing to it that people left them more competent than they came to them---they would want as many customers as possible

claim: DMO can offer multiple degree levels because individual courses have guaranteed meaning
text: DMO can offer multiple degree levels because individual courses have guaranteed meaning
quote: the greater the guarantee that a given course has meaning, and the greater the degree of specificity as to what meaning is, the fewer courses a student will have to take in order for that student to be recognized as having merit

claim: Students must be able to test out of courses to ensure instructors provide value rather than gatekeeping
text: Students must be able to test out of courses to ensure instructors provide value rather than gatekeeping
quote: DMO always offers students the ability to 'test out.' In other words, a student can get a given accreditation just by passing the examination in question: no time need be spent 'in class.'... As long as students have the option of testing out, it is guaranteed that students only pay instructors for actual instruction

claim: The inverted payment pyramid at DMO creates lean and functional operations
text: The inverted payment pyramid at DMO creates lean and functional operations
quote: At a conventional university, the money flows down. Students pay the university; the university pays instructors. The result: expensive and bad education. At DMO, the money flows up

claim: DMO will eliminate disciplines without practical value or objective assessment
text: DMO will eliminate disciplines without practical value or objective assessment
quote: Disciplines that have no practical value should either be jettisoned or modified so to have practical value... Disciplines that do not admit of objective assessments should either be jettisoned or modified so to admit of such assessments

claim: Student evaluations should be minimized in favor of performance-based instructor assessment
text: Student evaluations should be minimized in favor of performance-based instructor assessment
quote: The use of student evaluations should be minimized or eliminated. Student input should concern professionalism of instructor. The instructor's merit should be determined by student-performance, not by opinion or sentiment

claim: DMO hiring will be based solely on proven success with student outcomes
text: DMO hiring will be based solely on proven success with student outcomes
quote: Hirings are to be made exclusively on proven or probable success helping students pass accreditation exams. Therefore, publications are irrelevant to hiring decision, and so are letters of reference

claim: Existing universities cannot and should not be reformed
text: Existing universities cannot and should not be reformed
quote: There is little hope of reforming unviersities. They don't want to be reformed, and they don't stand to gain by being reformed

claim: Universities depend on inefficiency and poor knowledge management for their business model
text: Universities depend on inefficiency and poor knowledge management for their business model
quote: universities depend for their very existences on poor knowledge management... Universities fall into this category. They do provide some legitimate services, but these only account for a fraction of their revenue, the rest coming from overpriced ancillary services

claim: Universities have vague and incoherent objectives that prevent effective knowledge management
text: Universities have vague and incoherent objectives that prevent effective knowledge management
quote: Their objectives are therefore vague and incoherent, and it is correspondingly unclear what kind of information university-employees should make one another aware of

claim: The solution is creating new results-based educational services rather than reforming universities
text: The solution is creating new results-based educational services rather than reforming universities
quote: The right way to provide the public with better instruction is to create a new kind of educational service that is results-based and whose revenue is hewed to its pedagogical efficacy
